description: Negotiation is the art and the science of creating good agreements. This course develops managerial negotiation skills by mixing lectures and practice, using cases and exercises in which students negotiate with each other. The cases cover a wide range of problems and settings: one-shot deals between individuals, repeated negotiations, negotiations over several issues, negotiations among several parties (both within and between organizations), and cross-cultural issues. Performance in the cases accounts for nearly half the course grade. Students must also describe their experience and thoughts in a journal, and write a term paper.
name: NEGOTIATIONS

values.comments:
This course develops managerial negotiation skills by covering a wide range of problems using lectures, cases, practice and exercises. Performance in the cases accounts for close to half of a student’s grade. Other requirements include a student journal and term paper.

Students found this class fun and challenging. They seemed to really appreciate the “hands on learning.” Many students expressed some mild frustration with the grading system wishing negotiations were “not graded, or graded in a different style.”

Nearly every student echoed praise for Professor Rick. Many described him as both “challenging and entertaining” and said Professor Rick was “phenomenal.” One student said his “humor made everything easier to remember and apply.”

This class is highly recommended and many students asked Professor Scott not to leave for Michigan. Many students gave it the ultimate compliment by calling it the “best class at Penn.”
